PostValue.explanation: This is an administrative/community announcement: quite useful to EA members for planning, recruitment, local organising and outreach (including inaugural events in new countries), but not a load‑bearing or foundational claim. If true or false it only modestly affects who attends or organises events and the short‑term growth of the movement. For general humanity the direct impact is negligible (any broader effects are indirect and long‑term at best).

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Clarify the applications vs registration contradiction for EA Summits — right now you say Summits “typically do not require formal applications” but many Summit entries list application close dates. This will confuse readers. Action: explicitly state which Summits require applications versus open registration, link to the correct registration/application pages, and fix the wording so it’s consistent.

2) Add a small but high-value practical info column or note for each event — e.g. registration vs application link, in-person/hybrid, expected cost or scholarship info, primary language, and intended audience level. Action: either add a one-line clarifier per event or a short FAQ at the top (cost, travel support, accessibility, languages). This reduces follow-up questions and improves conversions.

3) Check and (if needed) hedge factual claims about “first ever”/“inaugural” events. If you’re not 100% sure those are firsts in a country/region, rephrase to avoid potential inaccuracies (e.g. “one of the first” or “inaugural for CEA-supported events in X”). Action: verify with event leads or CEA comms and update the copy.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback catches a clear contradiction (saying Summits typically don’t require applications while many Summit entries list application close dates) — that’s an own-goal that will confuse readers and is easy to fix, so calling it out is high-value. The suggested per-event practical details (registration vs application link, format, cost/scholarships, language, audience) would materially improve usability and reduce follow-ups; it risks lengthening the post but can be implemented compactly (one‑line clarifiers or a short FAQ). The caution about “first ever/inaugural” claims is sensible to avoid factual errors or embarrassment. Overall the points are actionable and address important accuracy/usability issues without requiring major rewrites.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No identifiable presence in major EA/rationalist channels (LessWrong, EA Forum, 80,000 Hours, prominent EA orgs) or in mainstream academic/media sources as of my 2024-06 knowledge cutoff. The name (or pseudonym) Arthur Malone🔸 appears not to be a known EA/rationalist author or public intellectual; it may be a niche/pseudonymous online alias with little to no broader visibility.

PostClarity.explanation: Well structured and easy to follow: clear headings, consistent event listings with dates, deadlines and links, and a helpful section explaining event types. The purpose and calls to action are obvious. Minor weaknesses: slightly long/repetitive (multiple apply prompts), small formatting inconsistencies (punctuation, one http link), and a few places where deadlines/tentative status could be highlighted more compactly. Overall clear and usable, but could be a bit more concise and visually scannable.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is essentially an events/registration announcement and logistical schedule. For EA Forum readers it contains no new arguments or concepts (just dates/locations), so it's not novel. To the general public it may be somewhat newsworthy (e.g. inaugural/local events, EA Global in NYC), but it still presents routine information about conferences rather than original ideas or claims.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: This is mainly an informational/announcement post rather than a deep argumentative piece, and its reasoning is clear, well-structured, and appropriate to its purpose (listing events, explaining event types, and telling people how to apply). It provides direct links to event pages and sensible distinctions between EA Global, EAGx, and EA Summits, which supports its claims about what is happening. Weaknesses: a few subjective claims (e.g., "an incredible number" or "reach more people than ever before") lack supporting metrics, there is no empirical evidence of expected attendance or impact, and some assertions about inaugural/first events are not independently verified in the post. For an announcement, the evidence is adequate; for stronger claims about scale or impact, more data would be needed.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post’s factual claims (events, dates, and application-deadline notices) are supported by the official EA/CEA events pages. I checked the EA Global events listing and the individual event pages (EA Global: New York City; EAGx São Paulo, Berlin, Amsterdam, India, Australasia; and EA Summits in Paris, Vietnam, New Zealand, Vancouver, Istanbul, etc.), and the dates/application deadlines match those pages. A few small items are ambiguous or slightly inconsistent with the current official pages: (a) the post’s claim that São Paulo applications were “just extended until August 18” is not reflected on the live EAGxSãoPaulo page I saw (it shows a different apply-by date), and (b) the wording that the Paris and Istanbul events are “inaugural” is explicit for Vietnam and New Zealand but not clearly stated on the Paris or Istanbul pages. Overall: well-supported, with only minor/date/wording discrepancies.
sources: EffectiveAltruism.org — Upcoming conferences / EA Global events listing (EA Global events page). ([effectivealtruism.org](https://www.effectivealtruism.org/ea-global/events?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
